title: Abdominal drainage to prevent intraperitoneal abscess after appendectomy for complicated appendicitis
authors: Tang, Y; Liu, J; Bai, G; Cheng, N; Deng, Y; Cheng, Y

response.output:
Plain Language Summary Title
Using a surgical drain after an operation for a burst appendix: does it help or harm?

Key Messages
– We are very unsure if using a surgical drain after an operation for a burst appendix helps to prevent a pocket of pus (an abscess) from forming inside the belly. A surgical drain is a soft tube placed into the body to remove fluid after an operation.

– Using a drain after an operation for a burst appendix probably increases the risk of dying.

– People who have a drain may also stay in the hospital longer, but we are very unsure about this.

What is complicated appendicitis?
The appendix is a small tube connected to the large intestine. Appendicitis happens when the appendix becomes swollen and infected. It is a medical emergency that usually requires an operation to remove the appendix, called an appendectomy.

Sometimes, appendicitis becomes 'complicated'. This means the appendix has burst or started to decay. Complicated appendicitis is more serious and can lead to problems after surgery, such as infections inside the belly.

After an operation for complicated appendicitis, some surgeons place a soft tube, called a drain, into the belly. The drain is meant to remove any infected fluid and prevent a pocket of pus, called an abscess, from forming. However, doctors are not sure if using a drain is helpful or harmful.

What did we want to find out?
We wanted to find out if using a surgical drain after an operation for complicated appendicitis is better than not using one.

We were interested in how using a drain affects:
– pockets of pus inside the belly (abscesses)
– wound infections
– other health problems after surgery
– death
– how long people stayed in the hospital

What did we do?
We searched for studies that looked at using a surgical drain compared with not using a drain in people who had surgery for complicated appendicitis. The people in the studies could be children or adults.

We compared and summarized the results of the studies and rated our confidence in the evidence, based on factors such as study methods and sizes.

What did we find?
We found 8 studies that included 739 people who had an operation for complicated appendicitis. In these studies, 370 people had a drain placed and 369 did not.

Pockets of pus (abscesses) and other health problems
We are very unsure if using a drain makes any difference to the number of people who get an abscess or a wound infection after their operation. We are also very unsure if it affects the risk of having other health problems.

Death
Using a drain probably increases the risk of dying within 30 days of the operation. In the studies, 7 out of 291 people who had a drain died, compared with 1 out of 290 people who did not have a drain.

Length of hospital stay
People who had a drain may have stayed in the hospital about 1.5 days longer than those without a drain. However, we are very unsure about this finding.

What are the limitations of the evidence?
We have very little confidence in most of our findings. This is because there were problems with how some of the studies were done. Also, the studies were small and their results were not always consistent.

The finding that drains may increase the risk of death is serious. However, it is based on a very small number of deaths in total. We need larger and better studies to be more certain about the benefits and harms of using drains after this type of surgery.

How up to date is this evidence?
The evidence is up to date to October 2023.
